terms.source: adhesive on the tips of his legs
terms.context: Physical feature allowing Gregor to hold himself upright against the door; specific sensory detail describing his transformed body's capabilities.
terms.notes: 다리 끝의 접착성 물질 (dari kkeut-ui jeobchakseong muljil) translates the technical description literally. This maintains Kafka's matter-of-fact description of the transformation's biological details.

terms.context: The clock on the chest of drawers that failed to wake Gregor: 'he could see from the bed that it had been set for four o'clock.' Symbol of time pressure and obligation.
terms.notes: Standard Korean term for alarm clock. '자명종' maintains the mechanical, precise quality associated with time pressure and obligation central to Gregor's anxiety.

terms.context: Physical description of Gregor's transformed body: 'He lay on his armour-like back.' Emphasizes the hard, protective quality of his new exoskeleton.
terms.notes: Direct, literal translation that preserves the simile structure and visceral quality of the original. '갑옷' (armor) conveys hardness and protection; '같은' maintains the comparative structure.

terms.context: The stair railing that the chief clerk desperately grabs with both hands while retreating, emphasizing his panic-stricken flight.
terms.notes: 난간 (nangan) is the standard Korean term for a stair railing or banister, essential for describing the physical action of the chief clerk's panicked escape.

terms.context: Official representative from Gregor's workplace who arrives to investigate his absence; speaks with authority and demands explanation from Gregor
terms.notes: Used '과장' (department head/chief) to convey workplace authority and hierarchy. Alternative '수석 사무원' (chief office worker) is also valid but '과장' better captures the authoritative tone.

terms.context: Alternative term for Gregor's profession; indicates traveling salesman role
terms.notes: More formal variant of travelling salesman. Could also use '외판원' for consistency with the primary term, but this fuller version emphasizes the 'commercial' aspect when needed for distinction.

terms.context: Physical description of Gregor's transformed body used to explain how others might help him move
terms.notes: Translates the physical description literally. '볼록한 부분' (rounded protuberance) captures the dome-like shape that is tactilely important to the narrative.

terms.context: The narrow passage that Gregor cannot navigate with his broad body, becoming a physical trap
terms.notes: Standard term for doorway; the narrowness is emphasized in context rather than translation itself

terms.context: The strong wind from the window that the mother opens, creating environmental chaos in the room
terms.notes: Korean term for wind or draft; maintains the environmental disruption and chaos the scene creates

terms.context: Spatial location connecting the flat's main room to the landing and stairs; critical to the geography of the family's reaction and the chief clerk's escape.
terms.notes: 현관 (hyeongwan) is the standard Korean term for entrance hall/foyer. Alternatives considered: 입구 (entrance), but 현관 better captures the domestic architectural space.

terms.context: Hobby tool mentioned by mother as evidence of Gregor's modest interests; used to make small wooden frames
terms.notes: Traditional Korean term '실톱' (jeweler's/fretsaw) specifically refers to this fine detail saw. Shows Gregor's modest, humble hobbies as an ordinary person before transformation.

terms.context: The protagonist who has mysteriously transformed. The text uses 'Gregor' as the primary name.
terms.notes: Romanized in Korean script following standard literary practice. '그레고르' for first name, '삼자' for surname maintains consistency with the source text.

terms.context: Gregor's severe injury from being violently shoved through the doorframe into his room
terms.notes: Direct translation maintaining visceral quality; 심하게 emphasizes the severity as original text requires

terms.context: Animalistic sounds the father makes to frighten Gregor, 'like a wild man'
terms.notes: Onomatopoeia in Korean that conveys threatening, animalistic quality of the father's aggression

terms.context: Former military rank visible in the photograph on the living room wall showing Gregor in uniform with sword, indicating his past social status and respectability.
terms.notes: 중위 (jungwi) is the standard Korean military rank equivalent to lieutenant, crucial for conveying Gregor's former social respectability.

terms.context: Multiple appendages Gregor now possesses; repeatedly referenced as he learns to navigate with them
terms.notes: Direct translation maintaining the diminutive quality ('작은' = little/small) that conveys both the creature's new form and Gregor's struggle to coordinate them.

terms.context: Professional summoned by Gregor's father to force the door open, though ultimately Gregor opens it himself using his jaw and teeth.
terms.notes: 자물쇠 수리공 (jamulssoe surigong) is the literal Korean equivalent for locksmith, combining 자물쇠 (lock) + 수리공 (repairman/craftsman).

terms.context: The boss's subordinate who monitors employees: 'The office assistant would have been there to see the five o'clock train go.' Represents workplace hierarchy and surveillance.
terms.notes: Korean office hierarchy term that conveys the subordinate monitoring role. '사무' (office) + '보조원' (assistant) clearly indicates administrative rank and surveillance function.

terms.context: Description of the father's initial composure before he panics at the chief clerk's flight
terms.notes: Captures the father's initial restraint before losing control; uses adjective form natural in Korean

terms.context: The chief clerk's walking stick seized by Gregor's father and used as a weapon to drive Gregor back into his room
terms.notes: Traditional Korean term for walking stick; in this violent context, maintains the physical reality of the weapon

terms.context: The commercial goods Gregor sells: 'A collection of textile samples lay spread out on the table.' Represents his profession and current obligations.
terms.notes: Standard Korean business/commerce terminology. '직물' (textile) and '견본' (sample) clearly convey the merchandise aspect of his traveling salesman profession.

terms.context: Gregor's profession. Referenced multiple times: 'Samsa was a travelling salesman' and 'travelling salesmen live a life of luxury.' Important to Gregor's identity and financial obligations.
terms.notes: Standard Korean term for traveling sales representative. More idiomatic than literal translation, conveying the professional status and commercial context essential to Gregor's character and motivation.

terms.context: Business/sales metric; chief clerk criticizes Gregor's poor turnover performance recently
terms.notes: Standard Korean business term for sales turnover. '매출' directly conveys the commercial metric that the chief clerk uses to criticize Gregor's work performance.

terms.context: He found himself transformed in his bed into a horrible vermin. German 'Ungeziefer' is deliberately ambiguous and should not be translated as a specific insect type.
terms.notes: Chosen over '벌레' to maintain the sense of repulsion and degradation while preserving ambiguity. '해충' conveys pest/noxious creature without specifying exact insect type, capturing Kafka's deliberate vagueness.

terms.context: Injury marks left on the white door when Gregor's body scrapes against it, suggesting bleeding and damage
terms.notes: Combines disgust (흉한) with physical description; visceral detail appropriate to literary horror register

terms.context: Used by the doctor's perspective via Gregor's thoughts: the doctor believed 'no-one was ever ill but that many were workshy.' A judgment about avoiding work.
terms.notes: Rendered as phrase '일을 회피하는' (work-avoiding/shirking) rather than single term, capturing the pejorative judgment and cultural context of workplace discipline common to both Western and Korean cultures.
